content: alright there's going to be a fun one
I've long wanted to do a tabletop feature with actual flowing water so
you'll need your soldering iron for this one and let's go get to it at the heart
of things is this a water pump designed to be powered by a 9-volt battery I get
this in Amazon for about 10 bucks it's intended to be a replacement part for a
coffee maker now the intake and outlet are different
sizes and finding the right plastic tubing for both would probably be around
20 bucks so I figured why not use drinking straws for the outflow it
happened to fit perfectly so I'll just seal it in place with hot glue around
the ring the intake is a much bigger diameter so I applied a thick bead of
hot glue to narrow it and quickly dipped it in water so that it would cool and
harden and not droop now straw fits perfectly and again I can hot glue all
around it but don't attach the outlet just yet wait until later in the project
also go ahead and solder on some lead wires with lots of slack and cover those
connections with hot glue so one-inch-thick extruded polystyrene
or home insulation draw out roughly where you want the pools to be I aim for
an overall based footprint of about 16 inches across and then kind of divided
it up from there then I use the proxxon hot wire table to
cut it out although you could use a knife a quick note Jeremy over at
Blackmagic craft is an Amazon affiliate for the proxxon hot wire table so if you
decide to buy one do it through him it's the same cost to you but he gets a
little taste all you got to do is click the link in the description below and
then make the purchase as normal anyway next I cut out two shapes roughly the
same size as the middle level with the top one being about an inch too long in
one direction and then four shapes for the top level stack again with the top
one being too big these overhangs help insure that the
water actually Falls instead of dribbling down the side of the cliff
faces for the mid-level stack we can go ahead and hot glue them on right now for
the top level stack we need to hollow it out take off the top piece and set it
aside for the other three cut out their centers leaving about an inch of
material if you use the Hotwire simply reattach
where you had to enter with hot glue now pick one of them to be the bottom
and trace the inside onto the base and cut out that as well we'll refer to this
as the pump pay while you're at it cut out the large bottom most pool as well
put the pump in place where you intend it to go then cut out a notch for the
intake pipe now you can attach the first ring and secure the pump in place I use
some kebab skewers in multiple directions with a whole lot of hot glue
to fix it where I wanted if you need a refresher on basic
electrical components and soldering revisit episode 56 here is an SBS T
switch and a 9-volt battery clip they will be connected to the pump in series
not in parallel here is a 12 inch sheet of chipboard the stuff that I always use
if you want to buy some you can do it for me as an Amazon affiliate by
clicking the link in the description below anyway just trace the base of the
piece onto it and cut it out it's okay to leave off an inch or so to make it
smaller so it doesn't stick out the sides also trace out and cut a hole for
the pump bay attach it to the bottom with the glue of your choice and then
apply a thick bead of hot glue all around the perimeter to create our first
watertight seal so here's where we're at so far I did punch a hole in which to
mount the switch with a bunch of hot glue to keep it firmly in place I also
attached the outlet pipe note that I chopped the straw near the bendy portion
and now I can aim it wherever I need to later on I also sealed up the hole
around the inlet pipe with lots of hot glue for the middle-level apply pure
acetone as we did back in episode 67 be sure to leave a u-shaped perimeter like
you see here and don't apply too much do it gradually until you get the depth
you're happy with attach the third ring so it kind of
overlaps the middle pool just a little bit apply acetone to the top level and
then kind of see where the outlet pipe is going to hit it you want the pipe to
emerge through the top somewhere near the back of the acetone pit punch a hole
using a pencil style foam cutter or kabob skewer whatever it takes
attach the top level while at the same time pushing the straw through the hole
apply a ring of hot glue around the
straw to make a watertight seal and then snip off the excess of the straw as much
as you can so that it's perfectly flush with the seal now I was worried about
water jetting out of the outflow so I took some foam carved a rock and hot
glued that to the top to solve the problem this also kind of gives it the
impression of being an underground spring or something like that as for
sealing the bottom pool I was figuring this out as I went along so you don't
need to do all of these techniques but I first tried covering it with hot glue
did not work so then I took some acrylic water kit mixed it up but instead of
using it for its usual purpose I took a sacrificial brush and slathered it on as
a sealer making sure to get all the nooks and crannies to help ensure the
water does fall instead of dribble a hot glue on some popsicle sticks at a 45
degree angle and then tease hot glue over them to blend them into the rocks
also attach some chunk of foam to the sides like this
and here's the first full wet test run if you want the water more spread out
like an actual waterfall attach some rocks to the popsicle stick to split up
and disturb the flow but I didn't bother one more thing I used some air dry clay
and built barriers around all the pool edges this gave me some nice texture and
it also created another quarter inch of depth for each pool which is another
nice safety feature we can also see I added a small island to the large pool
in order to make things more interesting then I based everything in grey dry
brush with light grey
wash with blacks mostly water apply homemade sawdust flocking you can
revisit episode 45 for that
and paint the water pools brown I'm using my airbrush at the edges of the
pool to get a real nice gradient fade to the gray and I'll say it again if you're
on the fence as to whether or not to get an airbrush do it you'll love it the kit
I recommended in the description below and you can buy it through me as an
affiliate comes with everything you need I also airbrushed on some patches of
dark green ponds are not blue they're brown and green and lastly a safety coat
of liquitex gloss varnish for all the wetted surfaces and before we go to the
table I'd like to take a moment to thank all wcv sponsors this week I draw your
attention to heroes horde which is an excellent resource for 3d printed
scenery including but not limited to Altru tiles products so if you're into
3d printing even if it's just to supplement your conventional crafting it
is worth a click to check it out and see what's what so the filling procedure is
like this fill up the middle level fill up the bottom level
and finally fill up the top level and as soon as you start hearing some
suctioning sounds that means that the pump and the pipes are filled up so flip
on the switch if the pump is not flooded or primed it will not draw any water
from the bottom pool so by pouring water from the top we ensure that it drains
down and Prime's the pump for us now is this practical
no is it aesthetic honestly no I've seen Pro made waterfall terrain pieces that
look better than this although to be fair if you're a longtime follower then
you know that outdoor stuff is not my forte how about the pump we'll take a
listen yeah again it's a coffeemaker replacement so it's not designed to be
quiet definitely getting enough water I tested
it in the sink before all this began that's just the sound that it makes so
what do we have here well it really serves no purpose other than itself and
isn't that the very definition of art so we have a piece of art with plenty of
mistakes in it but maybe one of you out there will take it and run with it with
the advantage of all the lessons that I learned so I am why lock thank you for
joining me and I'll see you next time
